trustfund:
TF025406-PHRD-RWANDA POST CONFLICT
            REHAB. AND REINTEGRATION TA PROJECT,TF021432-UN SPECIAL INITIATIVE FOR AFRICA

abstracts.cdata!:
Despite a satisfactory project outcome,
            sustainability is unlikely, and institutional development
            impacts were negligible. Lessons are summarized as follows.
            In hindsight, it is recognized that the narrow focus on the
            population control rationale in the original project design,
            would have served better had the approach been on
            people-centered health and welfare, bringing about effective
            behavioral change. Nonetheless, authorities are now
            re-thinking family planning approaches based on its
            contribution to improved health and welfare of mothers and
            children, rather than just for macro-demographic goals, a
            comprehensive approach currently being adapted at the policy
            level. In addition, while the restructuring of the project
            addressed important issues that Rwanda faced during the
            period of emergency reconstruction, greater attention should
            have probably been given to demand-side issues: health
            districts which put in place effective community financing
            schemes, experienced an increase in utilization of health
            services, highlighting the importance of complementing
            capital investments, with demand side measures. Other
            lessons suggest contracting production of communication
            materials to the private sector; channeling funds for
            HIV/AIDS activities and modalities of this type to community
            groups, accompanied by capacity building; and, addressing
            more comprehensively the issue of human resources needs, to
            ensure sustained development in the health system, in
            addition to maintaining a strong project management unit
            staff, knowledgeable with Bank procedures.
